examples.title: Sending Money to a Friend Abroad
examples.scenario: Sarah wants to send $500 to her friend John who lives in Germany. She initiates a wire transfer from her Chase Bank account to John's Deutsche Bank account.

steps.description: Sarah logs into her bank's mobile app and enters John's IBAN (DE89370400440532013000), amount ($500), and reason ('Birthday gift'). She submits the transfer request.
steps.technical: Chase Bank creates a pain.001 (Customer Credit Transfer Initiation) message with Sarah as Debtor, John as Creditor, and Deutsche Bank as Creditor Agent.

steps.description: Chase Bank validates the format and sends an immediate confirmation to Sarah that the payment has been accepted for processing.
steps.technical: pain.002 (Customer Payment Status Report) sent to Sarah with status ACTC (Accepted Technical Validation) or ACCP (Accepted Customer Profile).

steps.description: Chase Bank validates Sarah's account has sufficient funds, converts the pain.001 into a pacs.008 (FICredit Transfer) message, and sends it through the SWIFT network to Deutsche Bank.
steps.technical: pacs.008 message includes all payment details, unique UETR (transaction reference), currency conversion instructions if needed, and routing information.

steps.description: Deutsche Bank receives the pacs.008, validates the IBAN, converts USD to EUR at the daily rate, and credits €475.20 to John's account.
steps.technical: Deutsche Bank sends a pacs.002 (Payment Status Report) back to Chase confirming successful acceptance. John's account is credited and he receives a notification.

steps.description: At end of day, both banks generate account statements. Sarah sees -$500 debit, John sees +€475.20 credit. Banks settle via correspondent banking arrangements.
steps.technical: camt.053 (Bank to Customer Statement) messages are generated for both Sarah and John showing the transaction details in their respective account statements.

possible_errors.scenario: If John's IBAN was incorrect
possible_errors.result: Payment would be rejected and returned to Sarah

possible_errors.scenario: If Sarah only had $450 in her account
possible_errors.result: Chase would reject the payment before sending

possible_errors.scenario: If transaction was flagged for compliance review
possible_errors.result: Payment would be held pending investigation

key_takeaways: Cross-border payments involve multiple message types
Currency conversion happens at beneficiary bank
Each payment has unique UETR for tracking
Multiple banks may be involved in routing

examples.title: Receiving Your Monthly Salary
examples.scenario: Emily works at TechCorp and receives her monthly salary of $5,000 via direct deposit. TechCorp uses Wells Fargo, Emily banks with Bank of America.

steps.description: TechCorp's payroll system generates a batch file with 500 employees' salary payments. Emily is one of them. The file is sent to Wells Fargo on the 1st of the month.
steps.technical: pain.001 message with 500 credit transfer instructions. Each instruction contains employee details, bank routing numbers, account numbers, and amounts. BulkPayment = true.

steps.description: Wells Fargo validates TechCorp has sufficient funds ($2.5M), splits the batch by destination banks, and submits to ACH network. Emily's payment is routed to Bank of America.
steps.technical: Multiple pacs.008 messages are created, grouped by receiving banks. Each message contains relevant credit transfers. Sent through ACH network with value date = next business day.
key_fields: Creditor Agent: Bank of America routing number

steps.description: Bank of America receives ACH file overnight, validates account numbers, and credits Emily's account at 6 AM on the 2nd. Emily receives mobile notification.
steps.technical: Bank of America sends pacs.002 acknowledgment to Wells Fargo. Simultaneously generates camt.054 (Debit/Credit Notification) for Emily's account.

steps.description: Emily checks her mobile app and sees $5,000 deposited with description 'TechCorp Inc. - January 2026 Salary'. Her new balance is $12,345.67.
steps.technical: Mobile app displays data from camt.054 notification. At month-end, full statement (camt.053) will include this transaction with all details.

possible_errors.scenario: If employee account number was wrong
possible_errors.result: ACH return, payment sent back to TechCorp

possible_errors.scenario: If Emily had closed her account
possible_errors.result: Payment rejected and returned to employer

possible_errors.scenario: If TechCorp had insufficient funds
possible_errors.result: Entire batch rejected by Wells Fargo

key_takeaways: Payroll uses bulk/batch payments for efficiency
ACH is the clearing system for domestic US payments
camt.054 provides real-time credit notifications
Value date may differ from submission date

examples.title: When a Payment Bounces Back
examples.scenario: Alice tries to send £200 to Bob to pay for concert tickets, but she accidentally enters the wrong account number. The payment is rejected and returned to her account.

steps.description: Alice wants to send £200 to Bob's account ending in 4567, but she accidentally types 4568. She submits the payment through online banking.
steps.technical: Barclays creates pain.001 with incorrect account number (4568 instead of 4567). Payment instructions appear valid at origination.

steps.description: Barclays validates Alice has funds, debits her account £200, and sends the payment through UK's Faster Payments Service to HSBC.
steps.technical: pacs.008 message sent through FPS with the incorrect account number. Alice's account shows immediate debit.

steps.description: HSBC receives the payment and performs validation. Account GB29HBUK40127612344568 does not exist in their system. Automated system rejects the payment.
steps.technical: HSBC generates pacs.004 (Payment Return) message with reason code AC01 (Incorrect Account Number). Payment is returned to Barclays within minutes.

steps.description: Barclays receives the pacs.004 return, credits Alice's account £200, and sends her a notification explaining the payment failed due to incorrect account number.
steps.technical: Alice's account is re-credited. camt.054 notification sent to Alice's mobile banking. She can see both the original debit and the returned credit in her transaction history.

steps.description: Alice contacts Bob, gets the correct account number (4567), and successfully sends the payment again. This time it's accepted and Bob receives the funds.
steps.technical: New pain.001 → pacs.008 flow with correct account. HSBC accepts with pacs.002 (ACCP status). Payment completes successfully.

possible_errors.scenario: Incorrect account number (as shown)
possible_errors.result: Payment returned within minutes/hours

possible_errors.scenario: If account was closed
possible_errors.result: Similar return with AC04 reason code

possible_errors.scenario: If account was blocked/frozen
possible_errors.result: Return with AC06 - Account blocked

possible_errors.scenario: If name doesn't match account
possible_errors.result: Some systems return with NARR (Narrative)

key_takeaways: Payment returns use pacs.004 message type
Return reason codes (like AC01) explain why payment failed
Modern payment systems return funds quickly (minutes to hours)
Always verify account details before sending
Original payment reference is maintained in returns

examples.title: Company Paying Multiple Suppliers
examples.scenario: MegaMart needs to pay 50 different suppliers for goods delivered in December. Amounts range from $1,000 to $50,000. They use their corporate banking platform to submit a bulk payment file.

steps.description: Accounts Payable team exports payment file from ERP system containing 50 supplier payments totaling $875,000. Each payment includes invoice numbers for reconciliation.
steps.technical: pain.001 message with 50 credit transfer instructions. Each includes structured remittance information with invoice references. Batch booking requested for efficiency.

steps.description: AP Manager logs into JPMorgan's CorporateConnect platform, uploads the payment file, reviews summary, and approves the batch. Dual authorization is required.
steps.technical: Portal validates pain.001 format, checks account balance ($900,000 available), applies corporate payment rules, and queues for second approver.

steps.description: After second approval, JPMorgan debits MegaMart's account $875,000, splits payments by destination bank and payment method (ACH vs Wire), and sends to clearing systems.
steps.technical: Multiple pacs.008 messages created: 45 payments via ACH (smaller amounts), 5 payments via Wire (larger/urgent). Each grouped by settlement method.

steps.description: Receiving banks process incoming payments. Wire transfers settle same-day, ACH payments settle next business day. Each supplier receives credit notification with invoice details.
steps.technical: Each receiving bank sends pacs.002 acknowledgment. Suppliers receive camt.054 notifications showing payment amount and which invoices are being paid.
key_fields: Settlement Date: Based on payment method

steps.description: Suppliers' AR systems auto-reconcile payments against open invoices using structured remittance data. MegaMart receives confirmation that all 50 payments were successful.
steps.technical: MegaMart receives pain.002 status report showing all payments accepted. Both parties receive camt.053 statements showing all transaction details for month-end reconciliation.

possible_errors.scenario: If one supplier's account number was incorrect
possible_errors.result: That payment returned via pacs.004, other 49 succeed

possible_errors.scenario: If MegaMart had insufficient funds
possible_errors.result: Entire batch rejected before processing

possible_errors.scenario: If batch was accidentally submitted twice
possible_errors.result: Second batch rejected as duplicate

key_takeaways: Bulk payments are processed as single batch for efficiency
Structured remittance info enables auto-reconciliation
Payment methods (ACH/Wire) affect settlement speed
Corporate payments often require dual authorization
Status reports track success/failure of each payment

examples.title: Understanding Your Bank Statement
examples.scenario: Michael wants to reconcile his business checking account for December. He downloads his electronic bank statement in ISO 20022 format to import into his accounting software.

steps.description: On January 1st, Michael logs into Citibank's business banking portal and requests his December 2025 statement in ISO 20022 XML format for his accounting software.
steps.technical: Portal generates a camt.053 (Bank to Customer Statement) message containing all December transactions for Michael's account.

steps.description: The statement shows opening balance, all debits and credits for the month, and closing balance. Michael sees 156 transactions: 89 credits (customer payments) and 67 debits (supplier payments, fees).
steps.technical: camt.053 contains structured entries. Each entry has Credit/Debit indicator, amount, value date, booking date, transaction reference, and counterparty details.

steps.description: Michael clicks on a large credit entry ($12,500 from ClientCorp on Dec 15). The statement shows full details: who sent it, what invoices it paid, and when it settled.
steps.technical: Each statement entry contains: Amount, Value Date, Booking Date, Debtor/Creditor info, Remittance Information (invoice refs), Bank Transaction Code, and unique Entry Reference.

steps.description: Michael imports the camt.053 XML file into QuickBooks. The software automatically matches $450,000 of transactions to open invoices using the remittance information.
steps.technical: Accounting software parses camt.053 XML, extracts remittance references, and matches to AR/AP. Bank Transaction Codes help categorize (e.g., PMNT=payment, FEES=bank fees, INT=interest).

steps.description: After reviewing the 11 unmatched items (mostly bank fees and one unknown credit), Michael completes reconciliation. His accounting system shows $52,167.25 matches the bank's closing balance.
steps.technical: Final reconciliation confirms all transactions accounted for. camt.053's closing balance becomes opening balance for January statement (camt.053 continuity).

possible_errors.scenario: Transactions missing remittance information
possible_errors.result: Manual matching required, slower reconciliation

possible_errors.scenario: Balance mismatch between books and bank
possible_errors.result: Investigation needed to find missing/duplicate entry

key_takeaways: camt.053 is the ISO 20022 format for bank statements
Statements include structured transaction details for auto-reconciliation
Value date shows when funds are available
Remittance info links payments to invoices
Electronic statements integrate directly with accounting software

examples.title: Canceling a Wrong Payment (Payment Recall)
examples.scenario: TechSupply's AP team accidentally sends $50,000 to the wrong vendor (WrongVendor LLC instead of CorrectVendor Inc.). The error is discovered 2 hours later. They need to request a payment recall before funds are withdrawn.

steps.description: AP Manager reviews sent payments and realizes invoice #12345 for $50,000 was sent to account ending in 7890 (WrongVendor) instead of 7891 (CorrectVendor). Original payment was sent at 9 AM, discovered at 11 AM.
steps.technical: Original payment sent via pacs.008 with unique UETR. Payment is in transit - debited from TechSupply but not yet credited to WrongVendor's account.

steps.description: AP Manager immediately contacts Bank of America, requests emergency payment recall. Bank initiates formal cancellation request through ISO 20022 recall process.
steps.technical: Bank of America creates camt.056 (FI to FI Payment Cancellation Request) message referencing original pacs.008 UETR. Reason code = CUST (Requested By Customer).

steps.description: Wells Fargo receives camt.056, checks if payment has been credited to WrongVendor's account. Payment is still pending in their clearing queue (not yet posted). They can honor the recall.
steps.technical: Wells Fargo validates the recall request, confirms funds not yet credited, and prepares to return the payment. Investigation completed within 30 minutes.
key_fields: Account Holder Notified: No (funds never posted)

steps.description: Wells Fargo sends camt.029 (Resolution of Investigation) accepting the recall, then generates pacs.004 (Payment Return) to return the $50,000 to Bank of America.
steps.technical: camt.029 confirms investigation closed with outcome = CNCL (Cancelled). pacs.004 returns full amount with reason code CUST. No funds ever appeared in WrongVendor's account.

steps.description: Bank of America receives the returned $50,000, credits TechSupply's account, and notifies AP team that recall was successful. Total recall time: 3 hours from error discovery.
steps.technical: TechSupply receives camt.054 credit notification. AP team can now send correct payment to CorrectVendor Inc. No financial loss occurred.

possible_errors.scenario: If payment was a duplicate transaction
possible_errors.result: Recall justified under DUPL reason code

possible_errors.scenario: If payment suspected to be fraudulent
possible_errors.result: Urgent recall with FRAD reason code, higher priority

possible_errors.scenario: If WrongVendor already withdrew the funds
possible_errors.result: Recall denied, must pursue legal recovery

key_takeaways: Payment recalls use camt.056 (Cancellation Request) message
Success depends on timing - before beneficiary withdraws funds
camt.029 provides investigation outcome
Reason codes (CUST, DUPL, FRAD) explain cancellation cause
Time is critical - faster action increases recall success rate

examples.title: Splitting Dinner Bill with Instant Payment
examples.scenario: Lisa and David have dinner together. David pays the $120 restaurant bill with his credit card. Lisa sends her half ($60) to David instantly using her banking app's real-time payment feature (RTP network).

steps.description: While still at the restaurant, Lisa opens her Chime app, selects 'Send Money', enters David's phone number (linked to his Venmo account), amount $60, and note 'Dinner split'. Taps 'Send Now'.
steps.technical: Chime creates instant payment instruction (pain.001 variant for RTP). Payment is flagged for immediate settlement via RTP network rather than next-day ACH.
key_fields: Creditor Lookup: Phone number → Venmo account

steps.description: Chime validates Lisa has $60 available, debits her account instantly (balance updates in real-time), and sends payment through The Clearing House's RTP network to Synchrony (Venmo's bank partner).
steps.technical: pacs.008 instant variant sent via RTP rail. Payment is irrevocable once sent. Settlement happens in real-time between banks - no batch processing.

steps.description: Within 5 seconds, Synchrony receives the RTP payment, credits David's Venmo balance $60, and sends push notification. David sees the money immediately - can spend it right away.
steps.technical: Synchrony sends instant pacs.002 acknowledgment (ACSC - Accepted Settlement Completed). Funds are immediately available - no holding period.

steps.description: Lisa's Chime app updates balance: -$60 with timestamp 7:23 PM. David's Venmo app shows +$60 with Lisa's note 'Dinner split' at same timestamp. Both can see transaction completed in real-time.
steps.technical: Both receive camt.054 credit/debit notifications in real-time. No waiting for next-day processing like traditional ACH.

possible_errors.scenario: If Lisa only had $50 in her account
possible_errors.result: Payment rejected instantly before sending

possible_errors.scenario: If David's phone number wasn't linked to any account
possible_errors.result: Payment fails immediately with 'recipient not found'

possible_errors.scenario: If RTP network was experiencing downtime
possible_errors.result: Payment fails, Lisa receives error to retry later

key_takeaways: Instant payments settle in seconds, not days
RTP (Real-Time Payments) is US instant payment network
Funds are immediately available - no holding period
Payments are irrevocable once sent (can't be recalled)
Similar systems: SEPA Instant (EU), Faster Payments (UK), FedNow (US)

examples.title: Setting Up Gym Membership Direct Debit
examples.scenario: Emma signs up for FitLife Gym membership at €49.99/month. She authorizes the gym to automatically debit her bank account monthly via SEPA Direct Debit. The gym needs to collect payment on the 1st of each month.

steps.description: During gym signup, Emma fills out SEPA Direct Debit mandate form with her IBAN, signs it, and authorizes FitLife to collect €49.99 monthly. Mandate ID: FITLIFE-EMMA-2026-001.
steps.technical: Paper/digital mandate created with Emma's authorization. Contains: Creditor ID (FitLife's unique identifier), Debtor IBAN, Mandate Reference, Signature. Required before any collections.

steps.description: On January 25th, FitLife submits February payment to Commerzbank. First payment requires 5 business days pre-notification (SEPA rules). Collection date: February 1st. Sequence Type = FRST (First).
steps.technical: pain.008 (Customer Direct Debit Initiation) created with sequence type FRST, mandate reference, and required pre-notification period.

steps.description: Commerzbank validates the pain.008, batches it with other direct debits, and sends via SEPA clearing system to Deutsche Bank 2 business days before collection (D-2).
steps.technical: pacs.003 (FI to FI Customer Direct Debit) sent through SEPA scheme. Includes mandate data for Deutsche Bank to validate.
key_fields: Clearing System: SEPA Direct Debit Core (SDD Core)

steps.description: On February 1st, Deutsche Bank checks Emma's account for sufficient funds (€49.99 available), validates mandate exists, debits her account, and sends confirmation to Commerzbank.
steps.technical: Deutsche Bank processes pacs.003, debits Emma's account, sends pacs.002 status (ACCP). Emma receives camt.054 debit notification. She has 8 weeks to request refund (SEPA right).

steps.description: Commerzbank credits FitLife's account €49.99. For next month (March), FitLife sends pain.008 with sequence type RCUR (Recurring). Only 2-day pre-notification needed for recurring.
steps.technical: March onwards use pain.008 with RCUR sequence. Shorter pre-notification (D-2 vs D-5). Last payment will use FNAL sequence. Emma can cancel mandate anytime.

possible_errors.scenario: If mandate was never signed or doesn't exist
possible_errors.result: Direct debit rejected, funds not collected

possible_errors.scenario: If Emma requests refund within 8 weeks
possible_errors.result: Bank returns funds to Emma, charges FitLife

possible_errors.scenario: If Emma only has €30 in account
possible_errors.result: Direct debit bounces due to insufficient funds

possible_errors.scenario: If Emma blocked direct debits on her account
possible_errors.result: Payment rejected - account blocked for direct debits

key_takeaways: Direct debits require signed mandate before collection
SEPA has 3 sequence types: FRST (first), RCUR (recurring), FNAL (final)
First collection needs 5 days pre-notification, recurring needs 2
Debtors can request refund within 8 weeks (consumer protection)
pain.008 initiates direct debit, pacs.003 is interbank message

examples.title: International Trade Payment via Letter of Credit
examples.scenario: GlobalTech imports $500,000 worth of electronics from China. To mitigate risk, they use a Letter of Credit (LC). Payment involves multiple correspondent banks, currency conversion (USD to CNY), and compliance checks.

steps.description: GlobalTech requests JPMorgan to issue LC for $500,000 in favor of ShenZhen Electronics. LC conditions: payment upon proof of shipment (Bill of Lading). Expiry: 90 days.
steps.technical: Trade finance process begins. LC issued as guarantee - JPMorgan commits to pay if conditions met. Not yet an ISO 20022 payment message.
steps.message_type: LC issuance (SWIFT MT700 / moving to ISO 20022 tsmt messages)
key_fields: Required Documents: Bill of Lading, Invoice, Packing List

steps.description: ShenZhen ships electronics via cargo ship, obtains Bill of Lading, and presents documents to Bank of China proving shipment occurred per LC terms. Bank of China validates documents.
steps.technical: Documentary collection process. Bank of China verifies all LC conditions met. Once satisfied, they request payment from JPMorgan.

steps.description: JPMorgan validates documents, approves payment. Routes $500,000 to Bank of China via correspondent banks. Path: JPMorgan → HSBC Hong Kong (correspondent) → Bank of China. Converts USD to CNY.
steps.technical: Multiple pacs.009 (FI Credit Transfer) messages. First: JPMorgan to HSBC (USD). Second: HSBC to Bank of China (converted to CNY at spot rate ~7.2, = ¥3,600,000).

steps.description: JPMorgan debits GlobalTech's account $500,000 + $150 wire fees. HSBC settles using nostro account with Bank of China. Bank of China credits ShenZhen's account ¥3,600,000.
steps.technical: Settlement happens via nostro/vostro accounts. Each bank sends pacs.002 acknowledgments confirming their leg. Complex multi-hop payment complete.

steps.description: GlobalTech receives statement showing -$500,150. ShenZhen receives statement showing +¥3,600,000. JPMorgan and Bank of China exchange MT950/camt.053 statements confirming all aspects of trade.
steps.technical: camt.053 statements generated for all parties. Includes references to LC, Bill of Lading number, and full payment chain for audit trail.

possible_errors.scenario: If documents don't match LC terms exactly
possible_errors.result: Payment rejected, discrepancies must be resolved

possible_errors.scenario: If compliance flags parties for sanctions screening
possible_errors.result: Payment blocked pending investigation

possible_errors.scenario: If currency conversion fails or rate expires
possible_errors.result: Payment delayed until FX rate confirmed

key_takeaways: Trade payments often involve multiple intermediary banks
pacs.009 is used for financial institution to financial institution transfers
Correspondent banks facilitate cross-border settlement
Currency conversion happens at intermediary or beneficiary bank
Letters of Credit mitigate risk in international trade

examples.title: Fraud Detection and Payment Block
examples.scenario: CompromisedCorp's accounts payable system is hacked. Fraudster initiates a $250,000 wire transfer to an overseas account. Wells Fargo's fraud detection AI flags the transaction as highly suspicious and blocks it before sending.

steps.description: At 2:00 AM, fraudster uses stolen credentials to access CompromisedCorp's banking portal, creates payment to unknown overseas account for $250,000 with generic description 'Invoice payment'.
steps.technical: pain.001 generated with red flags: unusual time (2 AM), first-time beneficiary, high amount, tax haven destination, vague remittance info.

steps.description: Wells Fargo's AI analyzes payment against fraud models. Score: 98/100 risk. Flags: Off-hours, new beneficiary, high amount, destination country, atypical pattern for CompromisedCorp. Auto-blocks payment.
steps.technical: Payment enters fraud queue before converting to pacs.008. AI triggers immediate hold. Compliance team alerted. Payment status = PENDING REVIEW.

steps.description: At 8:30 AM, compliance team calls CompromisedCorp's CFO to verify the $250,000 payment. CFO is unaware, confirms no such payment authorized. Identifies as fraud attempt.
steps.technical: Customer confirms unauthorized. Wells Fargo generates pacs.002 rejection with reason code AG01 (Transaction Forbidden). Payment never leaves the bank.

steps.description: Wells Fargo's fraud team documents incident, files Suspicious Activity Report (SAR), forces password reset for CompromisedCorp's accounts, and recommends security audit.
steps.technical: Internal incident case created. Regulatory reporting triggered (FinCEN SAR). Additional monitoring placed on account. No funds lost.

steps.description: CompromisedCorp receives notification via camt.054 that payment was blocked for fraud. They investigate their systems, discover malware, and engage security firm to remediate.
steps.technical: camt.054 debit notification with status 'Blocked - Fraud Detection'. Customer grateful payment stopped. Implements stronger controls (MFA, IP whitelisting, transaction limits).

possible_errors.scenario: Transaction forbidden (as shown in fraud case)
possible_errors.result: Payment blocked before sending

possible_errors.scenario: If beneficiary on sanctions list (OFAC)
possible_errors.result: Payment blocked for legal/regulatory reasons

possible_errors.scenario: If additional information needed for AML
possible_errors.result: Payment held pending customer clarification

key_takeaways: Banks use AI/ML to detect fraud in real-time
High-risk payments are blocked before funds leave the bank
AG01 error code indicates transaction forbidden (fraud/compliance)
Regulatory reporting (SARs) required for suspected fraud
Multi-factor authentication and transaction limits prevent fraud

examples.title: Tracking a Lost Payment

examples.title: Complex Cross-Border Payment Investigation
examples.scenario: GlobalCorp sends a $2M payment to SupplierLtd. The funds do not arrive after 5 days. GlobalCorp launches an investigation. The payment was held at an intermediary bank due to missing compliance info, then released, but with a deducted fee that causes a short payment.

steps.description: GlobalCorp initiates wire for $2,000,000 USD.
steps.technical: pain.001 (Customer Credit Transfer Initiation).

steps.description: Chase sends funds via SWIFT to Correspondent (Standard Chartered).
steps.technical: pacs.008 (FIToFICustomerCreditTransfer) sent to SCB. UETR generated.

steps.description: SCB holds payment for sanctions screening on 'SupplierLtd'.
steps.technical: Internal Hold. No message sent yet, or pacs.002 (Pending) if tracking enabled.
key_fields: Rsn: G003 (Credit/Debit Card Service? No, compliance check)

steps.description: After 3 days, GlobalCorp complains. Chase queries SCB.
steps.technical: camt.028 (Additional Payment Information? No, pacs.028 is Status Request, camt.027 is Claim Non Receipt. Let's use camt.056 or pacs.028. Typically pacs.028 for status).

steps.description: SCB replies asking for invoice details to clear compliance.
steps.technical: camt.029 (Resolution Of Investigation) or camt.026 (Unable To Apply). Often a free format or camt.026 requesting details.

steps.description: Provides invoice. Chase forwards to SCB.
steps.technical: camt.031 (Reject Investigation? No). Usually communicated via service message or camt.029 updating case.

steps.description: Clears payment but deducts $50 compliance fee.
steps.technical: pacs.008 forwarded to DBS. Amount: $1,999,950.

possible_errors.scenario: Transaction Forbidden
possible_errors.result: If blocked indefinitely

key_takeaways: Cross-border payments can get stuck at intermediaries
pacs.028/camt.029 handles investigations

steps.description: Pays BOC.
steps.technical: pacs.008 (payment) linked to LC.

key_takeaways: Trade finance involves document matching
Payment is conditional on documents

steps.description: Sends payment details directly to Bank B (MT103 equivalent).

steps.description: At 17:00 CET, the system calculates the end-of-day balance for Subsidiary FR. Balance: +€2,500,000.

steps.description: Debits Barclays London's account and sends funds via Fedwire/CHIPS to Barclays NY.
